user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UtList_Create:
```c
UtListHead_t *UtList_Create(uint32 NumTags)
{
    struct ListAllocator
    {
        UtListHead_t Head;
        UtListNode_t Tags[];
    };
    struct ListAllocator *NewList;
    UtListNode_t *        TagHead;
    size_t                ActualSize;
    uint32                i;

    ActualSize = sizeof(struct ListAllocator) + (sizeof(UtListNode_t) * NumTags);
    NewList    = (struct ListAllocator *)malloc(ActualSize);

    memset(NewList, 0, ActualSize);

    NewList->Head.Tags         = NewList->Tags;
    NewList->Head.NumberOfTags = NumTags;

    for (i = 0; i < NumTags; ++i)
    {
        TagHead       = &NewList->Head.Tags[i];
        TagHead->Tag  = i;
        TagHead->Next = TagHead;
        TagHead->Prev = TagHead;
    }

    return &NewList->Head;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
NewList = (struct ListAllocator *)malloc(ActualSize);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation: NewList points to newly allocated, mutable memory that is subsequently modified (fields initialized and updated). Making this pointer const would prevent those modifications. A violation of Rule 8.13 would occur if the pointer were declared or used as pointing to a non-modifiable (const-qualified) object when modifications are intended — e.g. if NewList were declared as const struct ListAllocator *NewList while the code then wrote to its members.
